I love these helpful videos.  Just one question though... why was it said in the last video (meiosis) that there are lots of things about these processes that we do not yet understand how they work, even though we can watch it work under a microscope, and then at the end of this video that it is not a miracle, it is science?  Yes, it is science, but is science not a miracle?  It seems pretty miraculous to me.  The more we know and understand, the more we understand that we don't know.  A well-known quote by Albert Einstein is that, "There are only two ways to live your life: as though nothing is a miracle, or as though everything is a miracle."  Although it is, and perhaps because it is more humbling, I choose the latter.  In part because the more we learn, the more we realize that there are many things we don't know.    I have the conviction that not only is all science a miracle, but that all miracles are done by science.  That our all-knowing God works by set laws of science to bring about his eternal purposes, like creating the Earth to start with, including the use of many laws of science that we know nothing about yet, but will someday.  I believe that science and the spiritual are one. That spiritual phenomenon work on scientific laws and scientific phenomenon work on spiritual laws.  That spiritual phenomenon are simply on a higher, more pure or advanced plane than what we think of as scientific phenomenon.  So, does science bring us closer to the Master Scientist or farther away?  That depends on whether we come to think we know everything, or whether, as Einstein and many scientists do, we wisely and humbly come to realize how much knowledge we lack.

A chromosome is a long piece of DNA with a specific set of genes on it. A chromatid is a chromosome that condenses during mitosis/meiosis. A sister chromatid is a replicated chromatid (connected by the kinetochore complex or separated in anaphase). A tetrad is two sister  chromatids from Mom associated with two sister chromatids from Dad. A bivalent is one set of sister chromatids (either from Mom or Dad) in a tetrad.

#13 - Meiosis: Where the Sex Starts  1. Somatic cells clone themselves through the process of mitosis 2. When two things aren't identical but have the "same relation" they're called homologous  3. Cells that have half of a full set of chromosomes are called haploid 4. When a specialized diploid cell splits in half twice, the process is called meiosis 5. During interphase I, the cell undergoes DNA Replication (long strings of DNA begin to duplicate) 6. In which phase do crossover and homologous recombination occur? Meiosis 1 7. Which pair of chromosomes does not always go through crossover or recombination? 23rd pair (sex chromosomes) 8. The X and Y chromosomes do not match up because they are not homologous 9. The pairs of homologous chromosomes line up during metaphase 1 10. The homologous pairs get pulled apart and migrate to either end of the cell during anaphase 1 11. The result of meiosis phase I is 2 haploid cells  12. In prophase II the process is exactly the same as mitosis, except that there is no DNA replication 13. During telophase II, the chromosomes uncoil into chromatin 14. The result of meiosis phase II is 4 haploid cells (23 chromosomes each) 15. The sex-determining chromosome comes from a sperm and egg 16. During egg production, one gamete is much larger. The smaller cells are called polar bodies  ps.... idk about number 15

You have some misinformation in your video. For one there is NO SUCH   THING  as  male sperm. They are all female. And also there is NO Y chromosome during meiosis phase when the cells are paring. Both of those sex cells are Xs which comes from the mother of the male. The same way the female is  born with all female embryos coming from her mother, is the same way the male is born with all  female embryos coming from the mother. HE IS A SHE.  Another thing is that males don't keep producing eggs from which their sperm comes. A male is nothing more than a degraded female. He has ovaries (scrotum) that come with embryos in them just as she does. His sperm comes from a split of the original embryos just as hers does. The only thing he is continuously doing is splitting his original embryos, but then so is she which is why she keeps sending 23  chromosome haploid cells down to her uterus and not 46 or 92 chromosome  diploid cells down to her uterus.

It's actually a common misconception that X and Y chromosomes have nothing to do with each other during crossing-over. In fact they CAN get tangled and exchange genes, and because they aren't homologous this can result in some really interesting situations in which some of the Y chromosome's DNA can cross over to an X chromosome during spermatogenic (sperm-making) meiosis. This X chromosome may then fertilise the ovum (which always has one X chromosome), and what you get is a fertilised ovum with two X chromosomes, but with some Y chromosome DNA too (even though there's no Y chromosome in the cells).  Usually, this doesn't affect anything, but there's a not-small chance that the gene that crosses over to the X chromosome will be a gene called "SRY-1", or "sex-determining region-1". This is the "trigger" for the production of testes, the genes for which are actually already on the X chromosome. This causes a zygote with two X chromosomes and no Y chromosome to develop testes (though, they cannot produce sperm because they lack the other parts of the Y chromosome), and thus develop as partially or wholly phenotypically male-typical. This is one of the many kinds of *intersex condition*, and the specific name for this condition is "SRY-1 Positive de la Chapelle's Syndrome".   Intersex people make sex determination WAY more complicated than just XX/XY, especially since chromosomes are overruled by hormone levels later in the gestation. So, it's important to remember that this is a part of development that's FREQUENTLY skipped over,  but really shouldn't be because it's very important!

It's not a closed circuit. A bunch of elements and energy is constantly entering the cell (carbon, magnesium, iron, hydrogen, electrons, protons, etc). Its not like its simply dividing (otherwise, it would grow smaller and smaller). Its growing, then dividing. Growing again (taking in materials and energy needed to divide) then dividing again.

The law only applies to the universe as a whole, and as adriel4040 pointed out much matter and energy are going into the process of creating those cells and organizing them. It is the same reason making a cake doesn't defy the law, it is true that you organize the specific parts that go into the cake, but then you're ignoring all the energy that is spent doing so, which becomes sound and heat, increasing the total entropy.

You just took all the science out of that haha. There was 11 billion years between the big bang and cells 'showing up'. In between which subatomic particles formed atoms, atoms formed molecules, some of those molecules formed amino acids, some of those amino acids formed proteins, some of those proteins formed DNA and RNA; the first living molecules that were able to replicate. As they replicated over billions of years, random mutations occured and some of them attracted other molecules such as phosphates and lipids; forming cell membranes and the first cells. So as you see, nothing biological really 'just showed up'. If we think about intelligent design and imagine how a watchmaker would make a watch; would they start with subatomic particles and put them in a box and hope that one day they would all jiggle together to make metal cogs, quartz crystals, and glass? If they did, you might have to wait 14 billion years for your watch! The laws of physics explain how life arose from non-living matter, intelligent design begs the question; why didn't it happen sooner?

Sperms and eggs come from germ line cells, which are the testes (where sperm comes from) in males, and ovaries (where the eggs come from) in females.

He's talking about meiosis. What you're thinking about is mitosis. Meiosis happens after fertilisation of a human egg occur (when sperm fuses with ovum). Before fertilisation, the sperm and ovum are haploid, which means that they have half the chromosomal number. After fertilisation, the fertilised egg is diploid, meaning they have twice the chromosomal number (due to fusion of mother's cell and father's cell), so now, there are enough chromosomes for the cell to undergo meiosis. haploid and diploid refers to wheter the chromosomes exist in homologous pairs or not. So during mitosis the cells never even become haploid - chromatides are pulled apart, but every cell contains one chromotide from each of the homologuos chromosomes. But during meiosis 1 the homologous pairs are seperated and thus the daughter cells are not diploid anymore. Also I don't know if this helps, but having only one chromatide per chromosoms isn't really a big deal, because the sister chromatides are identical and can easily be replicated. the 2 chromosomes of an homologous pair however, do contain different allels/genetic information. So if they are seperated, their information is "lost" for that cell.
